extendedIngredients.name: carrot
extendedIngredients.originalString: 1 large carrot, peeled and thickly sliced

extendedIngredients.name: heavy cream
extendedIngredients.originalString: 1/2 cup coconut milk or 1/2 cup heavy cream

extendedIngredients.name: stew meat
extendedIngredients.originalString: 1 pound veal stew meat, cut into 2" cubes

extendedIngredients.name: thyme
extendedIngredients.originalString: 2 sprigs thyme, tied with kitchen twine

extendedIngredients.name: yukon gold potatoes
extendedIngredients.originalString: 4 medium Yukon gold potatoes, washed and quartered

recipes.title: Veal Stew

winePairing.pairingText: Cabernet Sauvignon, Chablis, and Malbec are great choices for Stew. Full-bodied red wines like malbec and cabernet sauvignon are the perfect accompaniment for beef stew. Fish stew probably calls for a white wine, such as chablis. One wine you could try is Dumas Station Minnick Hills Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon. It has 5 out of 5 stars and a bottle costs about 69 dollars.

productMatches.title: Dumas Station Minnick Hills Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon
productMatches.description: This wine features fruit aromas of cassis and blackberry. Additional aromas include classic Walla Walla dusty spice box, plus pencil lead and leather. This is a rich and meaty wine, with layers of complexity. Our Minnick Hills Reserve will benefit from decanting while young, and maintain its solid structure for years to come. "The scent of this wine reminds me of my first leather jacket-a Navy pilot's vintage aviator jacket, purchased at our local surplus store. I loved that jacket." -- Pete Thorson, Hospitality

recipes.instructions: Heat 2 tablespoons ghee in a 2 1/2 quart Dutch oven over high heat and cook the veal until browned on all sides, 3 to 5 minutes. Reduce the heat to medium and add the onion and cloves; continue cooking, stirring frequently, until the onion softens and is beginning to turn translucent, about 5 minutes more.Add the carrot, celery, thyme and bay leaf to the pot and stir in the chicken stock. Increase heat to high and bring to a boil; reduce the heat, cover and simmer for 1 1/2 hours, or until the veal is tender. 20 minutes before the stew is done, add the potatoes to the Dutch oven, recover, and cook until the potatoes are fork tender.After the potatoes have been added to the stew, heat the remaining 2 tablespoons of ghee in a sauté pan over medium-high heat. Add the mushrooms in a single layer, taking care not to crowd them, and cook, turning frequently, until the mushrooms are nicely browned. Remove the pan from the heat and set aside.Once the meat and potatoes are done, remove them from the Dutch oven using a slotted spoon and add them to the mushrooms in the sauté pan; keep warm. Pick the thyme sprigs and bay leaf from the the liquid in the pot (you may also remove the celery if you wish).Whisk egg yolks and coconut milk or heavy cream together in a bowl, and slowly stir into the liquid in the Dutch oven. Cook over very low heat for 10 minutes, stirring frequently, taking care not to let the mixture boil. Return the meat, potatoes and mushrooms to the pot; stir in the lemon juice. Taste, season as needed with salt and pepper, and serve.Nutrition (per serving): 604 calories, 30.8g total fat, 263.8mg cholesterol, 490.9mg sodium, 1657.5mg potassium, 46.5g carbohydrates, 5.4g fiber, 8.4g sugar, 35.9g protein.

steps.step: Heat 2 tablespoons ghee in a 2 1/2 quart Dutch oven over high heat and cook the veal until browned on all sides, 3 to 5 minutes. Reduce the heat to medium and add the onion and cloves; continue cooking, stirring frequently, until the onion softens and is beginning to turn translucent, about 5 minutes more.

Add the carrot, celery, thyme and bay leaf to the pot and stir in the chicken stock. Increase heat to high and bring to a boil; reduce the heat, cover and simmer for 1 1/2 hours, or until the veal is tender. 20 minutes before the stew is done, add the potatoes to the Dutch oven, recover, and cook until the potatoes are fork tender.After the potatoes have been added to the stew, heat the remaining 2 tablespoons of ghee in a sauté pan over medium-high heat.
Add the mushrooms in a single layer, taking care not to crowd them, and cook, turning frequently, until the mushrooms are nicely browned.

Remove the pan from the heat and set aside.Once the meat and potatoes are done, remove them from the Dutch oven using a slotted spoon and add them to the mushrooms in the sauté pan; keep warm. Pick the thyme sprigs and bay leaf from the the liquid in the pot (you may also remove the celery if you wish).

Whisk egg yolks and coconut milk or heavy cream together in a bowl, and slowly stir into the liquid in the Dutch oven. Cook over very low heat for 10 minutes, stirring frequently, taking care not to let the mixture boil. Return the meat, potatoes and mushrooms to the pot; stir in the lemon juice. Taste, season as needed with salt and pepper, and serve.Nutrition (per serving): 604 calories, 30.8g total fat, 263.8mg cholesterol, 490.9mg sodium, 1657.5mg potassium, 46.5g carbohydrates, 5.4g fiber, 8.4g sugar, 35.9g protein.
